et: contracted from Middle French {it}verdoyant{/it}, from present participle of {it}verdoyer{/it} "to be green, turn green," going back to Old French {it}verdoier{/it}, from {it}verd, vert{/it} "green" (going back to Latin {it}viridis{/it}, from a base {it}*wir-{/it}, whence {it}virēre{/it} "to show green growth, be green" of uncertain origin) + {it}-oier{/it}, factitive verb suffix, going back to Latin {it}-idiāre{/it}, originally representing variant pronunciation (or spelling variant) of {it}-izāre{/it} {et_link|-ize|-ize}

Latin {it}viridis{/it} and {it}virēre{/it} have been linked to Lithuanian {it}visti{/it} "to multiply, breed," {it}veisti{/it} "to breed, rear," as well as to Old English {it}wīse{/it} "sprout, stalk," Old High German {it}wisa{/it} "meadow," though the semantic connections are vague enough to make this a very tenuous hypothesis.
shortdef: unripe in experience or judgment : green
